speaker: Rob
text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Rob.

speaker: Sam
text: And I’m Sam, andI’m having a boiled egg for lunch today… I’ll just sprinkle some salt on top – there!

speaker: Rob
text: Oh, you’ve spilled some salt on the floor, Sam! Quick, throw some over your left shoulder.

speaker: Sam
text: Throw salt over my shoulder?! What are you talking about, Rob?

speaker: Rob
text: It’s bad luck to spill salt!

speaker: superstitions
text: Oh dear! It looks like Rob believes in superstitions - old beliefs which are based on magic and mystery rather than science. Many superstitions are connected to food, as we’ll discover in this programme.

speaker: Rob
text: Right - like throwing salt over your shoulder to stop bad luck.

speaker: Sam
text: Oh come on, Rob! You don’t really believe that, do you?

speaker: Rob
text: Well, lots of people do believe food superstitions, including otherwise rational, scientific people. For example, have you ever blown out the candles on a birthday cake and made a wish? Or thrown rice over the bride and groom at a wedding?

speaker: Sam
text: Yes to both of those. Maybe I’m more superstitious than I thought!

speaker: Rob
text: Well, before we find out, it’s time for a quiz question about another famous food festival – Halloween.

speaker: Sam
text: That’s when people carve scary faces into pumpkins to frighten away evil spirits.

speaker: Rob
text: Yes. Right. The tradition of carving pumpkins, or Jack o’ Lanterns as they’re called in the United States, started out as a Celtic festival in Ireland - but it was the Americans who started using pumpkins. So what vegetable did the Irish originally use to scare away ghosts? Was it:

speaker: Rob
text: a) turnips?

speaker: Rob
text: b) potatoes?,  or

speaker: Rob
text: c) squash?

speaker: Sam
text: I’ll say b) potatoes.

speaker: Rob
text: OK, Sam, we’ll find out the right answer later on. What’s for sure is that cultures from around the world have been connecting food and magic for thousands of years, and over time it’s created some strange beliefs.

speaker: Sam
text: Here’s food historian Tasha Marks describing one unusual superstition to BBC World Service programme, The Food Chain:

speaker: superstitions wards offward offevil eye’blanket term
text: When you have superstitions and they sort of mix with science and health and medicine… and one of the examples of that would be something like garlic which… we all know garlic wards off vampires but it’s also been thought to ward off the ‘evil eye’, and if you come across the term, the ‘evil eye’, it’s a sort of blanket term that sort of applies to any bad luck.

speaker: ward off
text: Tasha says that garlic is believed to ward off vampires, meaning to repel or stop someone from harming you.

speaker: evil eye
text: According to this superstition, garlic also keeps away the evil eye – bad luck or magical spells with the power to cause bad things to happen.

speaker: blanket term blanket term
text: Tasha describes the ‘evil eye’ as a blanket term for any bad luck. Just as a real blanket covers the different parts of your body, a blanket term is aphrase that’s used to describe many examples of related things.

speaker: Sam
text: But food superstitions aren’t only about bad luck - they also give our lives meaning.

speaker: Rob
text: Jonty Rajagopalan owns a tourist agency in Hyderabad, India, where she introduces visitors to some of the city’s food traditions.

speaker: Sam
text: Here she is talking with BBC World Service’s, The Food Chain, about a tradition connected with the Hindu New Year. Can you spot the different tastes she mentions?

speaker: lessonchutney
text: Some of the traditions give you a little bit of a lesson, like every new year, and not 1st January, not the Gregorian calendar New Year, but the Hindu calendar New Year, we would always be given… it’s a kind of a chutney which is made of all the five tastes:  so you have sour, you have sweet, you have something bitter in it and your mum would always give it to you saying that this is what the rest of the year is going to be – you’ll have happiness, you’ll have challenges, you’ll have a little sadness, you’ll have bitterness in your life, which I think is a very nice tradition – it prepares you for everything in life.

speaker: chutney –
text: At Hindu New Year, mothers give their children a special chutney – a mixture of fruit, spices, sugar and vinegar. Did you spot the chutney’s flavours, Sam?

speaker: Sam
text: There was sour, sweet and bitter.

speaker: Rob
text: Mothers tell their children that the coming year, like the chutney, will have its own flavours, both good and bad.

speaker: teach (you) a lesson
text: That’s why Jonty says that traditions can teach (you) a lesson – they show you what you should or shouldn't do in the future, as a result of experience.

speaker: Rob
text: What a lovely way to end our look at food superstitions!

speaker: Sam
text: Yes, maybe we should make chutney at Halloween, instead of carving pumpkins – or whatever vegetable the Irish originally used.

speaker: Rob
text: Ah, yes – in my quiz question I asked you what vegetable was originally used instead of pumpkins to scare away ghosts.

speaker: Sam
text: I guessed it was b) potatoes.

speaker: Rob
text: Which was… the wrong answer! In fact, turnips were originally used, so maybe Irish ghosts are smaller than American ones!

speaker: superstitions
text: OK, let’s recap the vocabulary we’ve learned about superstitions – old beliefs which are connected with magic.

speaker: ward off, evil eye -
text: Garlic is supposed to ward off, or keep away, dangers like the evil eye - bad luck or harmful magic.

speaker: blanket term
text: The evil eye is an example of a blanket term – a phrase used to describe many examples of related things.

speaker: chutney
text: One Indian superstition involves chutney – a food mixing many flavours

speaker: teach you a lesson -
text: These traditions can teach you a lesson - show you how to act in the future based on your past experience.

speaker: Rob
text: Right. Well, that’s all for this programme. Good luck with your language learning!

speaker: Sam
text: And if you’ve enjoyed this topical discussion and want to learn how to use the vocabulary found in headlines, why not try out our News Review podcast? Bye for now!

speaker: Rob
text: Bye bye!
